Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Functional Neuroimaging of Pain Attenuation in Experienced Meditators

POR.DRECONTENT:
We've all seen or heard fantastic stories about the exceptional abilities that some people have to endure pain. Some religious practitioners are able to resist pain even during agonizing rituals. Even laypeople can sometimes overcome extreme pain and continue to function, such as in a war zone, or in the birthing rooms of any hospital. We are interested in what happens in the brain when the body is in pain, and how we may be able to reduce the experience of pain by training the mind. We focused on the mental training technique of Buddhist Zazen meditation, which trains the practitioner to passively regard the stream of sensations which arise, and to separate them from the continuing sense of self. We used painful stimuli delivered with an innovative technique of intra-epidermal needle electrodes and recorded the rapid changes of magnetic fields at the scalp, which are an indicator of underlying neural activity. We showed that in naive subjects who had not meditated before, painful stimuli were rated as less painful during meditation, and neuromagnetic signals in the early stages of pain processing had decreased.

 

Our Zen monk subject, who had several decades of meditation experience, also reported that pain sensation decreased during meditation. However his neuromagnetic signals remained the same in the primary somatosensory cortices, and only decreased in the frontal and anterior cingulate cortices, which are higher-level processing and association areas. Our preliminary results contribute to the growing consensus within the discipline of cognitive and affective neuroscience that mental training can recruit top-down mechanisms to alter sensory perception. It may indeed be possible for someone to simply 'think away the pain', although researchers are still looking for the exact brain mechanisms underlying this phenomenon.

 

Over the course of this research project we actively sought out and engaged with members of the community who weren't typically involved in science and technology research. We visited many Buddhist temples and spoke with monks (through an interpreter), and gave accessible introductions to brain research in general, and on our research in pain and meditation in particular. It should be noted that the typical subjects used in the field of cognitive neuroscience are college undergraduates, and recently more attention has been paid to just how 'typical' these subjects are. How representative are their results for the general population? It is important to include wider and often-overlooked swaths of the population in brain-scanning studies. Over the course of our project we actively recruited monks who were typically older (above 50 years old) and somewhat more difficult to access. In the laboratory, our Zen monk subject proved to be inquisitive about our work and our rationale, and was an extremely motivated and cooperative subject. Following the experiment, we gave the monk a tour of our facilities and explained to him our immediate findings from his scan.

 

The elucidation of the neural mechanisms of pain and meditation clearly may contribute to medical practices in the future. Burgeoning research in alternative and complementary therapies may draw upon the base of neuroscientific knowledge to identify possible mechanisms, leading to a greater perception of legitimacy and to achieve wider public adoption.
